messages.text: <https://github.com/0x0f0f0f/Metatheory.jl|https://github.com/0x0f0f0f/Metatheory.jl>

elements.text: https://github.com/0x0f0f0f/Metatheory.jl

messages.text: "Metatheory.jl is a general purpose metaprogramming and algebraic computation library for the Julia programming language, designed to take advantage of the powerful reflection capabilities to bridge the gap between symbolic mathematics, abstract interpretation, equational reasoning, optimization, composable compiler transforms, and advanced homoiconic pattern matching features."

elements.text: "Metatheory.jl is a general purpose metaprogramming and algebraic computation library for the Julia programming language, designed to take advantage of the powerful reflection capabilities to bridge the gap between symbolic mathematics, abstract interpretation, equational reasoning, optimization, composable compiler transforms, and advanced homoiconic pattern matching features."

messages.text: Symbolics.jl uses the `Num` type on its `@variable` to do automatic tracing via `<:Number`. But that's not necessary for the CAS to work, it's just an enhancement.

elements.text: Symbolics.jl uses the
Num
type on its
@variable
to do automatic tracing via
<:Number
. But that's not necessary for the CAS to work, it's just an enhancement.

messages.text: When AbstractInterpreter functionality is better, that will likely replace it.

elements.text: When AbstractInterpreter functionality is better, that will likely replace it.

messages.text: But indeed, there isn't a single underlying piece of the symbolic representation. There are `Add`s, `Mul`s, `Num`s, etc. all working in harmony because of the generic interface. Pieces of the representation can be changed and swapped out without breaking Symbolics.jl user code to a meaningful extent.'

elements.text: But indeed, there isn't a single underlying piece of the symbolic representation. There are
Add
s,
Mul
s,
Num
s, etc. all working in harmony because of the generic interface. Pieces of the representation can be changed and swapped out without breaking Symbolics.jl user code to a meaningful extent.'

messages.text:
I noticed that RigidBodyDynamics have some examples of using symbolic manipulation using sympy for the dynamic equations of mechanical systems.
<https://juliarobotics.org/RigidBodyDynamics.jl/stable/generated/6.%20Symbolics%20using%20SymPy/6.%20Symbolics%20using%20SymPy/>
We do this a lot, using sympy and python, but have the following problem:
- for a robot with 2DOF, you can derive the equations by hand
- for 3DOF the calculations are very, very long
- for 4DOF sympy is happy to do them for you
- 5DOF takes a very long time
- 6DOF takes a weekend
- 7DOF forget about it

I would really like to be able to manipulate those equations using Symbolics.jl and use them inside MTK models,  but I find that I never get very far when I about once every second month try it out, I always stumble on something trivial and fail to interpret the error message. Are there any examples of manipulating such equations using Symbolics.jl and simulating them?

elements.text: I noticed that RigidBodyDynamics have some examples of using symbolic manipulation using sympy for the dynamic equations of mechanical systems.

We do this a lot, using sympy and python, but have the following problem:
- for a robot with 2DOF, you can derive the equations by hand
- for 3DOF the calculations are very, very long
- for 4DOF sympy is happy to do them for you
- 5DOF takes a very long time
- 6DOF takes a weekend
- 7DOF forget about it

I would really like to be able to manipulate those equations using Symbolics.jl and use them inside MTK models,  but I find that I never get very far when I about once every second month try it out, I always stumble on something trivial and fail to interpret the error message. Are there any examples of manipulating such equations using Symbolics.jl and simulating them?

```using SymPy

x, y = @vars x y
α, β = @vars α β

rhs = [α/(1 + y^β )  - x, α/(1 + x^β )  - y]
fps = solve(rhs, (x,y))```

messages.text:
There are 2 ways to support Complex numbers:

1. Use Complex (this leaves the question of what do we do with ‘@syms z::Complex’
2. Use a Term{Complex} wrapped in something like Num. but Num <: Real so it’s inaccurate. We could create a different wrapper type, but I'm kinda weirded out by having to add methods for that, but maybe it's not so bad.

elements.text: There are 2 ways to support Complex numbers:

1. Use Complex (this leaves the question of what do we do with ‘@syms z::Complex’
2. Use a Term{Complex} wrapped in something like Num. but Num <: Real so it’s inaccurate. We could create a different wrapper type, but I'm kinda weirded out by having to add methods for that, but maybe it's not so bad.

messages.text: 1. Also means that we need to make Complex itself behave like a tree and it cannot directly contain symbolic expressions but need to contain Nums

messages.text:
Can I get opinions on this?

```
#=
# There are 2 types of array terms:
#   `ArrayOp{T<:AbstractArray}` and `Term{<:AbstractArray}`
#
# - ArrayOp represents a Einstein-notation-inspired array operation.
#   it contains a field `.term` which is a `Term` that represents the
#   operation that resulted in the `ArrayOp`.
#   I.e. will be `A*b` for the operation `(i,) => A[i,j] * b[j]` for example.
#   The `.term` can be `Unknown()` if not known (e.g. after differentiation).
#   - calling `shape` on an `ArrayOp` will return the shape of the array or `Unknown()`
#   - do not rely on the `symtype` or `shape` information of the `.term` when looking at an `ArrayOp`.
#     call `shape`, `symtype` and `ndims` directly on the `ArrayOp`.
# - `Term{<:AbstractArray}`
#   - calling `shape` on it will return the shape of the array or `Unknown()`, and uses
#     the `ArrayShapeCtx` metadata context to store this.
#
# The Array type parameter must contain the dimension.
#=#```

elements.text: Can I get opinions on this?

#=
# There are 2 types of array terms:
#   `ArrayOp{T<:AbstractArray}` and `Term{<:AbstractArray}`
#
# - ArrayOp represents a Einstein-notation-inspired array operation.
#   it contains a field `.term` which is a `Term` that represents the
#   operation that resulted in the `ArrayOp`.
#   I.e. will be `A*b` for the operation `(i,) => A[i,j] * b[j]` for example.
#   The `.term` can be `Unknown()` if not known (e.g. after differentiation).
#   - calling `shape` on an `ArrayOp` will return the shape of the array or `Unknown()`
#   - do not rely on the `symtype` or `shape` information of the `.term` when looking at an `ArrayOp`.
#     call `shape`, `symtype` and `ndims` directly on the `ArrayOp`.
# - `Term{<:AbstractArray}`
#   - calling `shape` on it will return the shape of the array or `Unknown()`, and uses
#     the `ArrayShapeCtx` metadata context to store this.
#
# The Array type parameter must contain the dimension.
#=#

messages.text: The reason I'm using `ArrayOp`  is so that we can define differentiation easily. So those operations which can be einsum-like, will work right away. Any operation which cannot be expressed in Einsum (e.g. `\`) can be defined separate and derivatives have to be defined, but works seamlessly as leaf-nodes in  `ArrayOp` s

elements.text: The reason I'm using
ArrayOp
is so that we can define differentiation easily. So those operations which can be einsum-like, will work right away. Any operation which cannot be expressed in Einsum (e.g.
) can be defined separate and derivatives have to be defined, but works seamlessly as leaf-nodes in
ArrayOp
s

messages.text:
Hi, I just came across this weird behavior in `SymbolicUtils`, but I'm not sure if it's me or if I should open an issue:
```r1 = @rule(exp(~x) * exp(~y) => exp(~x + ~y))
           
@syms n x y
Prewalk(r1)(exp(x) * exp(y)) # as expected, returns: exp(x + y)
Prewalk(r1)(n * exp(x) * exp(y)) # unexpectedly returns nothing```
EDIT: simplified the MWE

elements.text: Hi, I just came across this weird behavior in
SymbolicUtils
, but I'm not sure if it's me or if I should open an issue:

r1 = @rule(exp(~x) * exp(~y) => exp(~x + ~y))
           
@syms n x y
Prewalk(r1)(exp(x) * exp(y)) # as expected, returns: exp(x + y)
Prewalk(r1)(n * exp(x) * exp(y)) # unexpectedly returns nothing

messages.text: I think that you may need `Prewalk(PassThrough(r1))`.

Prewalk(PassThrough(r1))

messages.text: Hi <@UBA5PL84U>, thanks for the answer. What I'm surprised about is that the rule just does not match. I think `Passthrough` just returns the expression if there is no match, but here I do expect a match. Just to be clear, I would expect to get `n * exp(x + y)` as a result of applying the rule (together with Pre/PostWalk).

elements.text: Hi
, thanks for the answer. What I'm surprised about is that the rule just does not match. I think
Passthrough
just returns the expression if there is no match, but here I do expect a match. Just to be clear, I would expect to get
n * exp(x + y)
as a result of applying the rule (together with Pre/PostWalk).

messages.text:
Maybe an even simpler example (which actually led me to try this other example) is that I want to be able to rewrite `n * sqrt(n)` to `n^(1.5)` but I have the same problem that this doesn't work:
```r1 = @rule sqrt(~x) => (~x)^(1/2)
SU.Prewalk(r1)(sqrt(n)*n) # -> nothing, but I expect a match```

n * sqrt(n)
to
but I have the same problem that this doesn't work:

SU.Prewalk(r1)(sqrt(n)*n) # -> nothing, but I expect a match

messages.text: Right, the issue is that it tries to match the whole expression using `r1`, which doesn't work and returns `nothing`. So then it tries to recursively apply `r1` to the arguments of the first transformation (which is `nothing`). This doesn't match either, and so the whole thing returns `nothing`.
